content.title: Glycemic Control in the ICU
content.summary: Hyperglycemia is common in critically ill patients due to stress hormones, medications, and nutritional support, and is associated with worse outcomes. However, the landmark NICE-SUGAR trial showed that tight glucose control (80-110 mg/dL) increased mortality compared to conventional targets (140-180 mg/dL) due to hypoglycemia. Current guidelines recommend targeting blood glucose 140-180 mg/dL, using IV insulin infusions in ICU, and avoiding hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL) which independently worsens outcomes.
key_points: Stress hyperglycemia: Common in critical illness; associated with poor outcomes
NICE-SUGAR trial: Tight control (80-110) INCREASED mortality vs conventional (140-180)
Target: 140-180 mg/dL for most ICU patients (NOT tight control)
Hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL): Independently harmful; avoid at all costs
IV insulin infusion: Preferred in ICU for flexibility and rapid adjustment
Check glucose every 1-2 hours on insulin drip until stable
content.statement: ICU glycemic management targets blood glucose 140-180 mg/dL using IV insulin infusions, avoiding both marked hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia, based on NICE-SUGAR trial evidence that tight glucose control increases mortality.

explanation.intuition: High blood sugar in sick patients was once treated aggressively, assuming that 'normal is always better.' But the body raises blood sugar during stress for a reason - it's fuel for the fight. Pushing it too low causes hypoglycemia, which damages the brain and heart. The sweet spot is in the middle: not too high, not too low.
explanation.key_insight: NICE-SUGAR was a game-changer. Before it, many ICUs chased 'normal' glucose (80-110 mg/dL). The trial showed this increased mortality by 14% - mostly from hypoglycemia. Now we know moderate hyperglycemia (140-180) is safer than tight control.
explanation.technical_details: Stress response increases cortisol, catecholamines, glucagon, and growth hormone, all raising glucose. Insulin resistance develops in peripheral tissues. Hyperglycemia impairs neutrophil function and wound healing. Hypoglycemia triggers catecholamine surge, arrhythmias, and neuroglycopenia. Point-of-care glucose meters may be inaccurate in shock (arterial sampling preferred).

definitions_glossary.stress_hyperglycemia: Elevated blood glucose during critical illness without prior diabetes
definitions_glossary.tight_glycemic_control: Target 80-110 mg/dL; no longer recommended due to hypoglycemia risk
definitions_glossary.hypoglycemia: Blood glucose <70 mg/dL; associated with harm
definitions_glossary.insulin_infusion: Continuous IV insulin for precise glucose control
definitions_glossary.glycemic_variability: Fluctuations in glucose; associated with worse outcomes
definitions_glossary.insulin_resistance: Reduced tissue response to insulin; common in critical illness
definitions_glossary.NICE_SUGAR: Landmark trial showing tight control increased mortality
definitions_glossary.counterregulatory_hormones: Hormones that raise glucose (cortisol, glucagon, catecholamines)
definitions_glossary.POC_glucose: Point-of-care glucose testing; may be inaccurate in shock

mechanisms: Nutritional support (dextrose in TPN, enteral formulas)

hypoglycemia_harm.evidence: Independently associated with mortality in ICU

Leuven_trial_2001.finding: Tight control (80-110) reduced mortality in surgical ICU
Leuven_trial_2001.limitation: Single center; high baseline glucose; nutritional protocols unusual

NICE_SUGAR_2009.design: Multicenter RCT; 6104 patients; intensive (81-108) vs conventional (140-180)
NICE_SUGAR_2009.finding: Intensive control INCREASED 90-day mortality (27.5% vs 24.9%; p=0.02)
NICE_SUGAR_2009.mechanism: Severe hypoglycemia 6Ã— more common in intensive group
NICE_SUGAR_2009.impact: Changed practice worldwide; ended tight control era

meta_analyses.conclusion: No benefit of tight control; increased hypoglycemia risk

insulin_administration.floor: Subcutaneous insulin; avoid sliding scale alone

monitoring.frequency: Every 1-2 hours until stable; then every 4 hours
monitoring.sample: Arterial preferred in shock; capillary may be inaccurate
monitoring.variability: Avoid large swings; glycemic variability associated with harm

elements: Starting rate based on glucose level
Rate adjustment algorithm (increase/decrease based on trend)
insulin_protocols.example_adjustment: If glucose 180-220: increase rate by 1-2 units/hr

recognition.symptoms: May be masked in sedated/intubated patients

treatment.glucose_40_70: D50W 25 mL IV; recheck in 15-30 min
treatment.glucose_below_40: D50W 50 mL IV; recheck in 15 min
treatment.investigate: Nutrition stopped? Medication error? Sepsis resolving?

considerations: Risk of DKA/HHS if insulin held
Check A1C to assess prior control

neurocritical_care.target: Some centers use tighter control (100-150) to protect brain
neurocritical_care.caution: Hypoglycemia especially harmful to injured brain

DKA_HHS.different_protocol: Treat underlying emergency with standard DKA/HHS management

definition.@value: Management of blood glucose in critically ill patients targeting 140-180 mg/dL to avoid harm from both hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia

scopeNote.@value: NICE-SUGAR showed tight control harmful; target 140-180 mg/dL

learning_objectives: Explain why tight glucose control is no longer recommended
Set appropriate glucose targets for ICU patients
Initiate and adjust IV insulin infusion
Recognize and treat hypoglycemia in critical illness
clinical_pearls: NICE-SUGAR: tight control (80-110) increased mortality 14% due to hypoglycemia
IV insulin infusion preferred in ICU for precise control
Check glucose every 1-2 hours on drip until stable
Avoid hypoglycemia (<70) - it independently increases mortality
common_misconceptions: Normal glucose (80-100) is always best - it increases mortality in ICU
Hyperglycemia doesn't matter - it's associated with worse outcomes
Sliding scale insulin is adequate - IV infusion is preferred in ICU

citations.title: Intensive versus Conventional Glucose Control in Critically Ill Patients

evidence.confidence_rationale: Landmark multicenter RCT; changed practice guidelines worldwide

sources.source: Marino's The ICU Book, 4th ed. Wolters Kluwer, 2014.
